Reviews.Content: My review will read negative. I did enjoy staying here, but wanted to counterbalance some of the overly-effusive 5 star reviews. I got off on the wrong foot with the property mostly over problems that were not the Hotel Langlois' fault. First, I had severe jet lag coupled with having landed in what I consider a confusing city. Second, I booked the room over a year ago when it had percolated to #2 on the tripadvisor rating scale (!) and hence was due to be disappointed. You need to remember that this is still an old style, two star hotel with all that that entails, i.e. street noise, paper-thin walls so that you can hear conversations next door, some rooms with tiny bathrooms, small closet space with not enough hangers, no ironing board, no coffee maker, no clock of any kind and finally a pleasant enough concierge whose job discription is less travel agent/confident (as you find in an expensive hotel) and more security guard/busybody. We were celebrating our 25th and were quoted 120 euros ($180 in my currency), not what I call 'budget'. The first room shown to us had a huge bathroom, and a view of...a wall. I asked to see another room and to her credit, the concierge showed me #63; tastefully decorated, tiny bathroom (but with tub, so usefull after walking all day!) and the killer view looking north at the Sacre Couer. We took it with no regrets. Moral; ask to see more than one room if possible. Getting back to the function of the concierge, when I asked for directions to a tourist bureau, she looked at me as if she had never been requested this before. Right then I knew I was on my own with regards to finding out what's on in town, making dinner reservations and deciphering the mass transit. When asking for multiple room keys, she explained the custom of only giving out one and when you leave, handing it to the person at the desk. I guess it's for security, but it can still get awkward when you both go off on seperate itineries. Anyway, I did get over the jet lag, calmed down and started to get in the vacation groove. And yes, I must agree that it is a very quaint hotel in a marvellous city. I loved the old, tiny elevator (reminded me of an old favourite in San Fran), just remember to close the inner door! The neighbourhood was nice as well, not touristy, but convenient to the sites and safe. You can feel like a Parissienne staying here. Below, dear reader, is some description of the locale to hopefully help you get acclimatized fast. As you step out of the hotel and head left towards the square you will run into a charmingly staffed patisserie. Patisseries in general (and this one is no exception) are the best deals in Paris. You can get a baguette, a delicious pastry and a 250 ml bottle of wine for less than 5 euros. One of our best remembrances was bringing said groceries back to the room, and snacking in front of the open window. Remember to bring/buy some wine glasses. Next to the patisserie is a nice cafe. Cafes are the worst deal in Paris. If you need a coffee, consider drinking at the bar like many commuters, you will be charged half the price. Also, they do not seem to have coffee-to-go in Paris and it is the next strongest thing to expresso. If you find it too strong, consider a cafe-au-lait. Next to the cafe is the Trinite metro located on the very convenient North-South #12 line. The metro is great, but can be daunting to a first-timer. This station has a manned booth but no photo-booth which you may need if you are considering the Carte d'Orange. I brought an extra passport photo which worked in the end. Walking is great in Paris but the metro is convenient and if I had to do it over again, would have taken the bus more. I would have killed for a map with the bus and subway lines justaposed over the streets, although I realise it would have been awfully busy. As you look out at the square, to your left is the way to Galleries Lafayette which is right next to the Opera which is where the RoissyBus drops you off. This is an economical and easy way to get to the hotel is you don't mind schlepping your bags four blocks. The map on the hotel website will make it easy for you to find it. Getting back to the square, if you go right instead for a short block, you will hit the Bistro des Deux Theatres, a prix-fixe only bistro where you get a kir, appetizer, entree, bottle of wine (limited selection), dessert and coffee for 33 euros. We found the experience fantastic. Finally, out of the hotel, if you head right instead of left and head up the road that veers north you will soon find the tiny Musee Gustave Moreau. If you are interested in the Museum pass, it's easiest just to buy it here, the clock does not start ticking until your first real visit. You will be hard pressed to break even on the pass, but it also can save you a lot of time in line. It gets you almost everywhere with the Eiffel Tower being the most notable exception. Also, even though my guide books were dated 2006, they wrote about 1,3 and 5 day passes when, in fact, they have moved on to 2,4 and 6. I hope these tips help you and just remember that the stereotype of the snootty French is most undeserved. Always say bonjour and try to speak there language no matter how broken your French is and they will meet you halfway and show you the secrets to their beautiful city. Bon voyage!

Reviews.Title: “Real Paris -”
Reviews.Author: Podger
Reviews.Content: My sister & I stayed here in May of this year. Of all the Parisian hotels I've stayed in over the years this has to be one of the best experiences. Near to just about everywhere you want to visit, close to buses and Metro, this hotel is in a less touristy part of Paris & in a more "authentic" area where local Parisians, work, shop and eat. Galleries Lafayette & Au Printemps are just down the street, the Opera House behind them. Monmartre is a short walk away along winding streets and then a short hike or 'Funicular" up to the Sacre Coeur area. The hotel was clean, quiet and friendly - plumbing excellent and breakfasts good.We had a room on the 4th floor overlooking the street which was very bright & we were not distubed by noise from traffic or other hotel guests. We took a taxi from Gare du Nord to the hotel but the metro is very easy & the station about 1 minute away. I'll stay here next time I visit Paris for sure.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic”
Reviews.Author: upstatetraveler
Reviews.Content: Fantastic! What a find. Located between two major rail stations and just steps from the metro, I can't imagine finding anything more satisfying. A very friendly and helpful staff, absolutely beautiful, clean and incredibly large rooms. Also beautiful elevator and staircases. Great breakfast (yes, extra cost, but well worth it) We have travelled a great deal in Europe and the Hotel Langlois is far, far above the norm. And at this price!! I would not hesitate to recommend it to friends and family and will certainly not bother to look elsewhere on our next trip to Paris. Absolutely tops!

Reviews.Title: “A Great Stay”
Reviews.Author: imabari
Reviews.Content: Myself, partner and 2 friends booked 2 rooms in the Langlois directed through their website after reading reviews on TripAdvisor. We paid about 100euro for each room which was excellent value. The rooms were spotless and perfectly sized (our friend's bathroom was huge!). Trinite metro was a mere 1 min walk away which was convenient for getting around. A taxi was less than 10 euro to the Lourve. We walked to the Moulin Rouge which was no more than 10mins away, with Montmarte a mere 20 min walk. We would all definitely stay there again as it was a terrific Parisian hotel and great value for money.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Choice”
Reviews.Author: Two_Wheels
Reviews.Content: This hotel was lovely and the staff friendly and helpful. It was located on a quiet street, near the Metro and bus to the airport. Wonderful bistro and restaurants in the area. Rooms were charming and clean. Bathrooms exceptional for Paris. Reasonably priced for Paris, too. We'll be back.

Reviews.Title: “absolutely lived up to my expectations”
Reviews.Author: tolo
Reviews.Content: My husband and I along with my daughter and her husband and my brother and his wife booked the Hotel Langlois when my daughter read the reviews on trip advisor. We were looking for a typical old charm hotel but also wanted some modern conveniences. The hotel langlois offers all of that. We were just so pleased with our rooms (we had a suite #24) and the staff was very helpful. They were very patient with my rusty French and they went out of their way do accommodate especially the day manager. They had replaced the carpet in the breakfast room and put in hardwood floor. Upon complimenting her on how nice it looked she then showed us a sample piece of carpet that they would be putting in all the rooms stating "this will be in your room when you next return" we laughed and assured her that when we do return to Paris we will definitely stay there again. We booked this based on these reviews and I am glad we did. We went on to Nice and were not so fortunate so after staying here the hotel there was a let down. We so miss our Hotel Langlois and the wonderful staff especially the blond woman on duty during the day as I spoke to her every day. I neglected to ask her her name however i told her of the web site and hope that they check it out. I am very fussy and this hotel more than met my needs.

Reviews.Title: “Best Value for the Money”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We are so glad we stayed at the Hotel Langlois in July 2006. We were there for three nights and the hotel was the best value for the money of any place we stayed on our two-week France vacation. We paid 120 Euros per night. The staff was very polite, friendly, helpful, and English-speaking. Hotel Langlois is extremely clean. The air conditioning worked perfectly. The hotel is in a great location. The metro is just a block away and the RER is about three blocks away. The easiest way to get from the airport to the hotel is to take the RER since you have the advantage of escalators and fewer changes when dealing with luggage. There is a computer in the breakfast area that you can use after 11am for free. It was very convenient. Breakfast is also served at the hotel for an additional price. However, there are also a variety of other places you can go to within walking distance. There was a refrigerator and TV in our room which were both very nice. Although the hotel claims their windows are soundproof, you can still hear a little bit of outside noise. However, since the hotel is located on a fairly quiet street the noise was not an issue. Printemps, a large department store is located nearby. We thoroughly enjoyed our stay and would definitely stay here again. We wholeheartedly recommend this hotel to other travelers.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel Langlois is everything as promised”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The Hotel Langlois was very easy to find, conveniently located (stone's throw from Metro Trinite, 5 minute walk to Gare San Lazare, 10 minute walk to Galleries Lafayette); safe neighborhood. Decor is old world charming French. Room very spacious (14), immaculate, adequately equipped. Proprietor very polite and hospitable. I was given 2 hour late check-out without problem. Internet use very available except during breakfast. Will have no hesitation to stay here again and have recommended hotel to friends and family in Paris and at home.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic”
Reviews.Author: ErichBakersfield
Reviews.Content: I read the reviews and saw the pictures of Hotel Langlois so I decided to give it a try. It was everything it adverstised. It is a beautiful little Paris Hotel that gives you a great Paris experience. We had the top floor family suite. It had two bedrooms, a kitchen and a bathroom. It had plenty of room for a family of four. The staff is very friendly and helpful. There is a great little bakery next door and cafes next to that. The metro is right around the corner that will take you anywhere in Paris. When I go back to Paris, this is the only hotel I will consider.

Reviews.Title: “Good, but some issues”
Reviews.Author: MOnica9
Reviews.Content: We chose this hotel based on a great review in a newspaper for our trip to Paris. My mother, father and myself booked a double room with an extra bed. The extra bed was very hard and not very comfortable. I woke up several times each night with pain in my back. Didn't feel very well rested in the mornings. My parents lied in the double bed and had no complaints about the bed. Another irritating thing was the housekeeper. One morning she came into our room without knocking. And although we were 3 people we only got two big towels. One morning I took one towel (for the next morning) from the trolley and put it in the room before we went out. When we got back in the evening she had been in the room and removed it. Very annoying to say the least. I had to use the small towel intended for use after hand- washing every morning. And why was she in our room when the room was already done? The people in the reception was just ok, not too friendly and they rarely even looked up from the computer when we passed the desk. Breakfast was ok, it cost 10 euros per person, the food was high quality and tasty. The aircondition worked fine (thank god, it was over 30 degrees fahrenheit every day) All in all a good experience and I would stay there again, but a little bit more friendliness from the staff and more discretion from the housekeepers would be nice.

Reviews.Title: “Great!!!!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Big rooms, big bathrooms!! All very clean!!! air conditioned in the room. Excellent!!! The staff is very friendly. Not expensive at all!! All was definitely perfect.

Reviews.Title: “Langlois Good Value”
Reviews.Author: max42044
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Langlois during a stay in Paris late last year. PROs: We found the staff to be friendly and helpful throughout the hotel (reception / breakfast room / housekeeping / etc) and believe the Langlois is good value for the money. We stayed in a suite on the street (St Lazare) side of the building but the noise was not a problem for us. There was an excellent pastry shop just down the road toward Trinite Square and a metro/subway station at the square. The metro is easy to navigate and you can get to any of the locations you would probably want to visit with little problem. We had a Paris Visite card which we had to validate the first time we rode on the metro which was an excellent value for us as it was essential for getting around to the major points of interest. The staff directed us to a laundromat which was in the opposite direction from the square where we were able to wash clothes. (We had been in Europe for a while before we got to Paris and were then continuing to London.) Although we were somewhat perplexed where to put our money to get the washers and dryers started a couple of locals patiently got us through it. There was a major shopping area Lafayette close by which my wife loved and where she claims she got some great bargains on what appeared to be an endless selection of lingerie. CONs: The hotel is somewhat off the beaten path. Although the metro system was excellent, still would have liked more variety nearby for meals and other amenities. Even though the breakfast (buffet style) was good; the breakfast room, just off the main entrance, was very small. It didn't take much of a crowd to find yourself cramped in and having to inconvience your fellow diners when trying to get to the breakfast table. Also the bed was somewhat uncomfortable and you could tell our suite was not orignally disigned as such. OVERALL: Will we stay here again the next time we are in Paris? Possibly! I think I will shop around a little more and use those resources available, especially this forum, to look for for something a little more centrally located and which would better suit our tastes. Having said that unless I could find something else which I felt really comfortable with I would have no qualms about staying at the Langlois again.

Reviews.Title: “Just what we expected!”
Reviews.Author: Middle-Age-Traveller
Reviews.Content: I booked this hotel after reading your reviews. Was a bit nervous as I was arranging the trip for myself and a French friend who might be critical but we were both delighted. The hotel is near to the Metro and to RER station Haussman-Lazare from Gare du Nord Magenta. We had large quiet room number 11 on first floor at rear of hotel, no view but lovely large bathroom with lots of character. Rooms spotless and towels changed every day. Dining room is small but pretty and lots to eat but you can have breakfast in your room at no extra cost, this is customary in Paris hotels apparently. The staff were friendly, my friend's French no doubt helped, she said that few of the staff were actually French although I couldn't tell from the accent. We had a super meal at les Deux Theatres restaurant, set menu with lots of choices for33 Euros inclusive of a bottle of wine between two and coffee plus a sparkling wine aperitif. The hotel is handy for the sights with a combination of metro and walking. We found that a Paris Museum Pass was handy to skip the queues at Musee d'Orsay and Louvre but didn't save money unless you are a museumaholic. Would definitely return to this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Break!!!”
Reviews.Author: pathni
Reviews.Content: I read the reviews on Tripadvisor and decided to book a three night break at the hotel Langlois, Paris. When we arrived we were warmly welcomed and were pleasantly surprised by the size and decor of our rooms. Lovely high ceilings and a real ambience that can only be experienced when in Paris! The hotel reception were always very helpful and friendly, and ensured that our stay was a memorable one. We asked about reservations for the Moulin Rouge show and the reception immediately contacted them and reserved our table...which ended up being one of the best spots in the theatre! As for location the Hotel Langlois is close proximity to everything, a 15 minute walk to Montematre, same again to the Champs Elysee, close to the large shopping centres, and with a metro within literally 50 meters nothing in Paris is more than a few minutes away. There are a number of relatively inexpensive cafe/ bistros close by and a delicious pattisserie at the corner. All in all I would highly recommend for anyone to stay at the Hotel Langlois, in fact I have booked my second stay for August this year!!!

Reviews.Title: “A Good Value and We Were Happy Here”
Reviews.Author: Spirit
Reviews.Content: We stayed here in early May, 2006. Considering the price of hotels in Paris, this hotel is quite a bargain. The staff are nice. Three of us stayed in a two room suite. We had a big bed and two sort of cot sized fold out beds. I didn't sleep on the fold out beds but apparently they were adequate. The rooms were quite spacious, they were clean, and service was good. The elevator is a relic of a long bygone era It's small and quaint, and in very good condition!. There are a pair of doors behind the front door of the elevator. These inner doors have to be closed for the elevator to work. Hotel guests keep forgetting to close those doors, or don't know they have to, and then the elevator won't move. The young man at the desk is frequently running up the stairs to get the elevator. (He is in very good shape!) We went to the corner café for coffee and croissants every morning, but the breakfast room in the hotel looked nice…starchy white tablecloths, coffee, big glasses of orange juice…I don’t know what else they had, but people in there looked happy! I had wondered if we would like the location of the hotel since it is in the 9th arrondissement. It turned out that I did like it. Most tourists stay in the arrondissements surrounding the Seine: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7. Those areas are maximally thick with tourists. After spending a day in the Saint Germain area I felt like I needed elbow room and was very happy to go back to the 9th which is mostly French. The Saint Lazare Metro station is at the corner of the hotel’s block. It could hardly be more convenient. A taxi stand is also at that corner. There’s a computer with Internet in the breakfast room which is available for use without charge. One of my friends made daily calls to Florida from our room and the charges for the calls were not high. We heard very little noise from the street in our rooms. All three of us were quite satisfied with this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “affordable and nice”
Reviews.Author: the_lowdown
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Hotel Langlois based on its reviews on tripadvisor and the reasonable price. There were 3 of us so they added a cot which was fairly comfortable. The high ceilings (we were on floor 2, which is really the 3rd floor in North America) made the room seem more spacious. The bathroom was quite large. It was almost as big as the bedroom. The place was clean. Located on a quiet street just steps away from the Metro. It's just 3 blocks north of the Opera, 2 block from the department stores, Lafayette and Au Printemps. The staff were friendly and helpful. We had blown a fuse using our North American adaptor and they were quick to fix it. There's an elevator. And free internet service in the small dining area. It was great value for our stay in Paris. We would definitely stay there again!

Reviews.Title: “Full of character”
Reviews.Author: travelreviewers
Reviews.Content: I chose Langlois because we prefer hotels with character rather than chain establishments and it certainly didn't disappoint. We stayed in room 41, which was spacious and well furnished. The bathroom was huge with a beautiful art deco sink and bath. The location was also great - we walked to the Louvre in about 25 minutes and back from Montmatre in 20. Getting to the hotel was really easy from the airport, as there's a direct bus to Opera which is a 10 minute walk from the Langlois. I would certainly recommend this place for people who are looking to stay somewhere a little bit different in the centre of Paris.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel -clean and friendly”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This hotel is rated 2* but we found on our one night stay that it was roomy, clean, friendly, peaceful and very French (ie not an anonymous multiple). The free newspaper at reception (a Guardian) and the free access Internet computer in the small dining room were a real bonus. We don't really understand why it is only 2*. We walked from Gare du Nord (overnight bag only) but it is extremely close to the Metro and the many buses. We had a magical walk from Sacre Coeur in the evening back to the hotel. We'll be going back.

Reviews.Title: “Well Located Langlois”
Reviews.Author: It_happened
Reviews.Content: Very good location for shopping, tourist attractions and transport links, be sure to get a room at the very top of the house as the rest are noisy (we had 4 rooms between our party all over the building). By Paris standards it is value for money, the rooms were a good size with decent bathrooms and were nice and clean. Breakfast is good but you can do as well in the cafe's locally for less money.

Reviews.Title: “Very Nice”
Reviews.Author: grdahl
Reviews.Content: Just what one expects from a Paris Hotel. Old world charm in great location. Rooms were good size and beds were comfortable.

Reviews.Title: “Great little French hotel”
Reviews.Author: HJC54
Reviews.Content: My college-age daughter and I stayed for 4 nights in March. The rooms was typical by European standards, nothing plush, but tastefully appointed. The bathroom was fine (the housekeeping at this hotel is excellent). What we really loved was the old world feel of the hotel...the staircase, tiny elevator with wrought-iron door, etc. We stopped at the bakery a few doors down for breakast each morning, then it was right to the Metro to travel easily all over central Paris. The location is excellent. I found the desk people very kind and helpful, particularly in the wee hours of the morning when I needed directions to the all night pharmacy! We would stay at Hotel Langlois again.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, wonderful service - but old and noisy hotel.”
Reviews.Author: sherry02
Reviews.Content: We stayed 7 days in Hotel Langlois (room 21)... Location is excellent, service was magnificent!!! Size of our room was OK, but the bathroom was small. Our friends stayed in room 22 - which was much larger with huge bathroom. Our room faced backyard - it was relatively quite (no noise from the street). But when somebody was walking in the room above/below our room - the floor sound like orchestra from Paris Opera. This is a VERY old hotel, which was not remodeled in ages. It is good hotel for the money you are spending, if noise is not an issue for you

Reviews.Title: “Disappointed”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Booked my 3 night stay here because of all the great reviews, even though it was a bit above my budget. When we arrived we found that some people had just been moved out of the room we had been assigned - we did not think anything of it at the time. After three nights broken sleep and now know why! The room was a good size and nicely furnished but really hot even with the radiator off and on opening the double glazed windows the noise from the traffic below was terrible - so much for a relaxing weekend! Also on Saturday night I was woken several times by blaring pop music and I could feel the bed move every time a metro train came through! In addition to this the bed was not very comfy and the breakfast was overpriced for what it was. I might pluck up the courage to stay here again, as everyone else seems to have had fun, but I would request a room facing off the street and higher up - avoid the front rooms on the first floor!!!

Reviews.Title: “Great little hotel”
Reviews.Author: Flitcraft
Reviews.Content: My daughter and I spent a week at the Hotel Langlois and highly recommend it. We had originally planned on not taking the optional breakfast, but ended up doing it almost every day for convenience and to fill us up for the day. In addition to the usual French pastry and bread they had sliced cold meat, eggs to boil, sliced cheeses, and Turkish cheese and oil cured olives. Also orange juice and tea if wanted plus plenty of good French cafe. Very convenient location--only a half block from the Trinite metro station, and about four blocks from the Opera Garnier (where the Roissybus from the airport stops). Also very close to an RER train station. Free Internet was useful, especially when I got very sick during my stay (nothing to do with the hotel!) and needed to check symptoms online, communicate with my health care at home, and order a wheelchair at the airport. The room we had was large by Parisian standards with two firm single beds and an immaculate roomy bathroom. Staff is multi-lingual and very helpful; you are steps from the Metro, and it isn't a tourist-ridden area--we didn't see a single Rick Steves book all week! Strongly recommend for a comfortable well-priced place to stay.

Reviews.Title: “Love it!”
Reviews.Author: PeonyThailand
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the hotel for six nights. The hotel is charming. The room is big. I got a room that did not face the street; so, it was very quiet at night. I thought it was almost too quiet! I found the bed to be a bit too soft for my own preferences. A metro station is just around the corner. I hopped on and off the metro almost the entire time I was there. There are a couple of great restaurants and crepe places around the corner that I went for breakfast almost every morning. I also really like the hotel's free Internet even though I didn't realize that the french has a little different keyboard system! But that just added to more fun! In sum, I had a great time staying at the hotel and would definitely recommend it to my friends and will stay there again in my next visit(s).

Reviews.Title: “Charming hotel, great location”
Reviews.Author: kkotcher
Reviews.Content: I found the hotel to be charming and the staff was friendly and helpful. We had room 21 -- we took a room without a view because we needed a bigger room for a family of three (full bed plus a rollaway). The rollaway was the most comfortable portable bed I have ever slept on! The bathroom was huge: we moved a table and chair in there and used it for hanging out at night when you woke up from jet lag and couldn't get back to sleep, but didn't want to wake the others! The room was insulated from the street noise, but the radiator pipes could be pretty noisy at night. I guess this would be my only complaint-- earplugs and Ambien solved this problem for me. I loved the location: lots of restaurants, cafes, metro stops, etc. nearby. Paris Opera House and Galleries Lafayette just 3 blocks away. There's a wonderful little wine bar across the street called La Garonne, and a bakery half a block away where we got breakfast every am (cost 1 euro compared to the 10 euro breakfast at the hotel-- great if you don't want to eat a large breakfast). We had a wonderful experience -- mom, 11 year old child, and grandma all in agreement.

Reviews.Title: “An Excellent Value-Can't Wait to Return!”
Reviews.Author: lacostamom
Reviews.Content: What a wonderful experience! This is a lovely hotel in a great part of town. Everyone was friendly and helpful. We were even upgraded to a suite on the top floor because they didn't have any more rooms with two single beds. It's just a few blocks away from the best shopping in Paris and only a block from the Metro. One note: Skip the breakfast there and eat at some of the great restaurants nearby or at the restaurant at Gallerie Lafayette (which looks out on the Eiffel Tower).

Reviews.Title: “Poor Service”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Stayed at this place based on the reviews of this website - I'm sorry I did. The service was very poor. I arrived at the hotel early in the morning with a confirmed reservation for a certain room type picked out from website. Was told that I couldn't check in yet - which was reasonable since it was before noon. Came back later in the day but was then told, oh sorry that room is not available despite my confirmed reservation and having presented myself earlier in the day?! The only room now is one on the ground floor right off the lobby facing the street (with traffic passing by). Why wasn't I told that when I got there that morning? I would have left and found a different hotel. But obviously when I came back it was too late to find another hotel. Guess they wanted to fill as many rooms as possible and gave mine away to someone who didn't want the "lobby" room. The attitude of the manager/desk staff was very poor. She half-heartedly tried calling for a cab. When the line was busy after one try she said sorry just find one on the street. Thanks for nothing. I would definitely not stay there again and if you do, don't count on your reservation.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful place - Very Parisian Flair”
Reviews.Author: AvidTravelers96
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel for our tenth anniversary and it is absolutely great! I was a little worried after reading some of the reviews but there were no problems. The radiator sounds that people had noted were nothing, if you have ever had radiators then you know the sound. And, the room was always a comfortable temperature. We had room 31, which has a huge bathroom -- HUGE and spotless. The room was neat as a pin as well as the whole Hotel. Staff were very nice and the street it was on was lovely, very convenient. We had breakfast in our room every morning and it was delicious. The smell at around 6AM til 11AM is heavenly, I am convinced that they magically pipe it into the rooms. Smells like baking bread!

Reviews.Title: “Will definitely be going back”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Hands down one of the largest rooms (and bathroom!!) I have ever seen in Paris, at a third of the price. Beautiful light from large windows which looked out into interior courtyard. Well located for public transportation (Metro, buses, Gare du Nord) and walking--straight up the hill to Montmartre in twenty minutes, or down to the Seine in 30. Responding to other reviews I would have to say that yes, the cleaning people were slightly aggressive, and there were some loud pipe noises, but nothing that took away from a generally excellent experience, or that would be unexpected in an older building. I managed to sleep very well in a comfortable bed. Great value!

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic Hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Spent our first wedding anniversary at this great little hotel and would definitely recommend it. The location was perfect - 2 minutes from Metro station, but the hotel is so central, that we rarely used it and tended to walk everywhere. Our room was great (6th floor)and the hotel in general was very traditional and quirky. We loved it. Didn't have breakfast as there are loads of bakeries nearby, but plenty of people did, so it must have been good! The staff were friendly and helpful and the hotel was kept beautifully clean. If you're after somewhere a bit different with plenty of Parisien charm and character, then this is a great hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel, good location”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed for a weekend at the Hotel Langlois and thought the hotel was fantastic. We were slightly apprehensive after reading the bad reports on trip advisor but we were pleasantly surprised. We even took ear plugs as there were many reports of the hotel being extremely noisy on your website. We arrived late on Friday night for the weekend and the staff were very courteous and friendly. We had a superior double room on the 5th floor. It was much larger than any other room in Paris we had stayed at (for the same price) and never encountered any noise problems whatsoever. A great location, only 10 minutes by bus from Gare du Nord, and 10 mins by metro to Musee D'Orsay. We will definitely stay here again when we return to Paris.

Reviews.Title: “Good location, good price, and a slightly mad cleaner!”
Reviews.Author: guba-7
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the hotel for 4 days with my wife, with mixed feelings. Good points: -It was in good location with access to the Trinite metro a few minutes walk away. - Good prices for Paris. - Plenty of cafes/brasseries nearby all serving decent food. Bad points: - the noises in the hotel were annoying. They were from the water pipes, heaters, and neighbours. - it was very hot. - the cleaners very overeager to say the least. One morning she came in at 9:30. And the other day, she wanted to clean the room whilst we were sleeping!!!! I appreciate she may have been busy, but come on! On the whole, the hotel has its charm, but the constant noises and the mad cleaners spolit the stay.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location!”
Reviews.Author: chandeb
Reviews.Content: Wonderful location! I took the Roissy bus directly from the airport to the Opera and the hotel was only a few blocks away through the shopping district. Sure beat lugging luggage up and down train and metro stations. Another good things about the hotel is that guests can use their computer/internet for free. The computer is in the breakfast room. We stayed at various hotels throughout France, this is highly uncommon. The hotel/room is old. The water pipe, at least I think that's what it was, in my room made loud beating noise sporadically throughout the day. I was so jetlagged that I slept through it but it would annoy me otherwise.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel Theft---Management Deception”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We just got back from our stay in Hotel Langlois, and had such a miserable experience that I feel I have to share it with other travelers. Our hotel room was robbed during our stay and the hotel managed this incident very poorly. Our almost entire wardrobe got stolen during the trip including many luxury brand items that you cannot necessarily fit into a safe. Some of these items were bought during their trip in Paris including luxury handbags and footwear. The robbery took place on the day before our departure. We are still investigating the matter, but we have not been compensated for our loss to this day and it seems like such an expensive stay for a 2-star hotel when you factor in our loss, not to mention the stress factor. I would stay away by all means. Here is a recap of the hotel theft incident: We entered the room one evening to find it all messed up and realized many of our belongings were missing from the room. We called the reception which then informed the manager. The manager apologized and told us they would compensate us for whatever was stolen. We said we would like to inform the authorities and make an official statement to the police. The manager told us this is unnecessary and asked us to make a list of stolen items. When we asked the manager if he could see in the computer any entries to our room other than housekeeping, we were told that there were none. However, one hotel staff did tell us later that our room was entered after the housekeeping left and before we arrived. We were puzzled. The next day, when we provided the manager with the total value of the missing goods, he proceeded to the closest bank and came back with a copy of a swift message for X Euros (total value of the stolen items) showing that this amount was transferred to our bank account and allowing no arguments or discontent on our part. The case seemed to be settled and closed. That day, we flew to London, relieved. When we came back home, we found out that the manager recalled the money from our bank without even informing us. We were told to deal with the insurance company. Well, as the hotel manager had told us at the time of the incident that it was unnecessary to call the police and issue an official statement, we were in no position to recover the total value of the goods from the insurance company. We had a wrong start. Had the hotel manager not provided us with the bank receipt showing X euros were transferred to our account the next day, our approach would have been more professional and official. We have been robbed and later deceived by the hotel management. We faced tremendous stress in dealing with this hotel theft situation. The hotel's management of the situation was far more stressful for us than the incident itself. Again, I would stay away by all means. After all, a vacation is meant to bring you peace and not stress.

Reviews.Title: “great”
Reviews.Author: templemd
Reviews.Content: The hotel is in a great location..convenient to both the trinite and lafayette metro stations. The rooms are very clean and generous in size. There is a great bakery just down the street for bread and pastery. For a great and local non-touristy dinner go to Les Comediennes next to trinite church. The staff are very helpful.We stayed for seven nights with two children in a suite. (Good choice if traveling with kids) We would definetly stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “a beautiful hotel and quiet ,good location ,safe”
Reviews.Author: lantus007
Reviews.Content: This has got to be the best hotel for the price.We had a standard room it was beautiful and clean.IT LOOKED LIKE THE WEBSITE.It had a black marble fireplace in the room with white marble reclining female nude statue and tall ceilings.It had a great bathroom, deep tub ,and a good bed.What more do u need for romance.The hotel is very special and has been the set for several movies.The hotel staff is very helpful. .The hotel is very close to Galleries Lafayette where we had breakfast every day on a terrace overlooking the Opera and Paris.Breakfast was cheaper by half at the department store.Have fun!

Reviews.Title: “We love it..”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My self and my husband we stayed here for 5 nights. This was our 3rd visit to Hotel Langlois. We just love the location, the decor, the rooms and friendly staff. We'll go back next year for sure.

Reviews.Title: “No better for the price or more”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This is simply the best hotel deal in Paris. Yes, the floors will have some creaks and unevenness. No, the rooms will not be absolutely quiet. And, yes, the furniture shows some age. But what some people consider drawbacks, others consider advantages. We stayed in the second floor (third floor for Americans) suite for over a week and found it a perfect place to come home to after a day of museums, stores, or gloriously aimless wandering. We came home to two large rooms with very high ceilings, marble mantels, some charming sculpture, two balconies, and--most of all--comfort. The hotel staff was friendly and helpful; the maid was an absolute charmer. If you want a slick hotel where all the staff is perfectly fluent in English, go elsewhere. If you can manage a bit of French and want to stay someplace where it feels completely like Paris, and if you want to do it at an unbeatable price, stay at the Hotel Langlois.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Hotel but Clangy Pipes at Night”
Reviews.Author: le juif errant
Reviews.Content: This is a difficult review to write, because the hotel was excellent on almost every level--larger than average room and bathroom for the price, friendly and helpful clerks (with the exception of a dour one at nighttime), close proximity to the Trinite metro, and free Internet access. We didn't notice in their e-mail confirmation that the continental breakfast wasn't free (cost 9 euros), but that was our fault. As attractive as this hotel is on many levels, I wouldn't stay here again, for only one reason: the noisy clanging pipes at night, which became unbearable. If you don't get much sleep, it can be hard to sightsee the next day.

Reviews.Title: “Brilliant!”
Reviews.Author: badly1004
Reviews.Content: We stayed here from 3rd - 5th January and find it very hard to fault the place. First of all the location is superb. To get there we just got off the bus from Beauvais at Port Maillot where we went round the corner to the Metro station and bought our 3 day tickets. From Port Maillot we travelled on to Concorde where we changed for Trinite. Although we took a wee while to find the hotel it's really very easy to find if you know where to look. Just come up the steps of Trinite Metro and take the street on your right - Rue St. Lazare. It's just along there a bit. From this station you can get anywhere within minutes. It's also within easy walking distance of the Moulin Rouge and the Opera. The hotel itself is very charming and we found the service to be excellent. The bed could be more comfortable but the room was huge and we had a shower, toilet, minibar and tv. We were lucky enough to have a room at the back so we didn't get much noise although it's in the middle of a big city so you should probably be prepared for that. Any time we asked for help at the reception we received it with a smile. My biggest tip would be to ask for a restaurant recommendation. You won't be disappointed. All in all if you want a place to rest your head for a decent price in the centre of Paris you can't really go wrong with this place.

Reviews.Title: “Not quite impressed”
Reviews.Author: Abby-m
Reviews.Content: I think one has to acknowledge from the very onset that what is good for one will not necessarily be for another. Like other people, I chose the hotel based on good reveiws but I must say I was disappointed. Except for the location and some helpful members of staff, in particular one very friendly and extremely helpful young lady, there isn't much that I liked about the hotel especially the room - from the decor to just the ambiance. Although the room was bigger than most of the hotel rooms I've seen or stayed at in Europe, I did not quite like it. The room was not sound proofed, making each and every sound from other rooms very audible including footsteps on a creaky wooden floor from the room above. I'm sure the occupant of the room below me also suffered, as my floor also creaked badly and I was restless for most of the time. I should maybe take some responsibility for not specifically asking for a non-smoking room, but it was as if people on my floor were on a smoking holiday. They would smoke until the small hours of the morning and by day break I would be literally choking. The bed was uncomfortable, 'caved in' and creaky, the pillows equally uncomfortable. I don't know if the heating system was not effective or if it was just me freezing. The lift is quite antique and intersting but it wasn't getting to my floor on some days.I think some travellers will still find the hotel ok, but personally I don't think I'll be returning.

Reviews.Title: “You Can Do Better in Paris”
Reviews.Author: Scott&Stacey
Reviews.Content: We stayed here 5 nights in mid December and we were going to return for 4 nights around New Years, but canceled our reservation and booked elsewhere. There were 3 major problems: the noise, the neighborhood, and --most importantly -- the poor value based on what you can find elsewhere. As for the noise, the sewage pipes and the radiator pipes are not insulated, so you hear every time someone in a nearby room flushes the toilet or showers. But the radiator pipes were the worst. Every night from 10pm to about 2am the pipes from the radiator clanged so loud it was impossible to sleep (even for a heavy sleeper), then the heat would be reduced and the room was chilled during the day. We asked to change rooms, but were told that it was an old system and that other guests had the same complaints and that there was nothing to be done. Don't expect to go to sleep any time prior to 2am because the radiator pipes will keep you awake. Furthermore, the hotel is not in a nice or convenient neighborhood. It's in a busy commercial district. You'll take the metro more than you need to and walk on ugly streets to get where you need to be. It's not the impression you want of Paris. Regarding the value, the Langlois is charging 110 euro for a standard double plus 9 euro for breakfast. So for 2 people, you're paying 128 euro because despite what other guests say, the breakfast is the best deal you'll find. You'll pay 9 - 12,50 euro plus tip for a similar breakfast on the street unless you get a pastry and coffee, which is neither healthy nor adequate for a morning of sightseeing. The 9 euro for a breakfast that includes yoghurt, cheese, and other sources of protein is reasonable. So 128 euro for a noisy, shabby room (We had one of the rooms pictured on the web. It's not so nice in person: terrible mattress, musty smell, and rickety furniture.), a poor location, and a not very helpful staff. Whereas we moved to the Hotel D'Angleterre, on Rue de Jacob in the St. Germain area and for 145 euro (which included breakfast) we had a charming room with a garden/courtyard view, easy walking distance to all the major sights (NOT METRO --the fares add up, by the way), a charming neighborhood that was a pleasure to stroll through, easy access to all sorts of cafes and bistros, a wonderfully helpful staff, a beautifully appointed lounge and breakfast room with lovely china (extensive buffet breakfast), and most importantly, a quiet peaceful place to sleep. Had we not moved hotels, we would have left Paris with a bad impression based on being tired and having to negotiate the horrible streets around the Langlois. It is a budget hotel charging mid-range hotel prices and at these prices, you can find accommodation that is much better and will make your stay in Paris much nicer.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Honnymooner
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the hotel with my wife for two nights on the 22-24 dec. The Hotel is lovely, in a great location and worth every penny of the 110 euros a night. I stayed in room 64 which was quite large with a smallish bathroom (All you need to get washed in). Found the staff friendly enough and had no problems with them. On the downside it was a bit noisy at night and the rooms were very warm but will stay here again the next time I go to Paris.

Reviews.Title: “Loved it”
Reviews.Author: samski
Reviews.Content: Stayed at Hotel Langlois from 19-24 December. At a total cost of 446.54 euros including two lots of taxes but excluding breakky, I had an absolutely fantastic stay and thoroughly enjoyed what the hotel and Paris had to offer. We stayed in Room 71. It is HUGE because it is basically half of the entire sixth floor with the dividing walls knocked down. Entry to Room 71 is via its kitchenette, complete with pots and pans, microwave and fridge; followed by the lounge room which had a table and 4 chairs, a TV, a futon sofabed and wardrobes; then twin bed bedroom with (another) TV, and finally a big bathroom with quite fancy towels and fawcett/basin. See the room pictures room and window views. On yeah, the lift is one of a kind. The receptionist girl was very friendly and helpful but she only works on certain shifts, and then a surly eastern European guy (who claims he speaks zero English) takes over from 6pm and everything goes downhill from there. There is a fast computer with broadband internet and a CD/DVD burner (perfect if your digicam's memory cards are low) in the breakky room. It is free for all patrons. When you walk out of the front door, take two successive right turns and you will be outside a small supermarket. I went nuts on the French gummy bears. I would say you do not have the 9 euro breakky at the hotel simply because there are so many alternatives available. The croissants from the bakery on the way to the metro are quite awful (but cheap, at 0.72 euro each), I don't know why everyone is recommending that place other than for reason of convenience. There are so many nearby cafes offering hot breakkies it's not even funny. Prices are all quite reasonable. There is a taxi rank outside Trinite, across the road from exit of the Trinite Metro. Very convenient. I found the hotel a bit too hard to find when I got off the Roissybus at Opera because of the strange shape of Rue St. Lazare. As it turned out, if you are facing Trinite, the portion of Rue St. Lazare where the hotel is situated is the SECOND narrow street on your RIGHT, after the Trinite Metro exit (in a kinda roundabout setting). Paris is absolutely wonderful. So is the Langlois. Not hard to guess where I will stay when I come back to Paris. Sam

Reviews.Title: “Worst European hotel experience we've ever had!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just returned from a 7 night stay at the Hotel Langlois. We have relied on TripAdvisor for choosing many of the hotels we have stay in in Europe and we’ve always been satisfied. But the Hotel Langlois was definitely an exception. We made reservations for a superior double with a large bathroom, but when we arrived, we were given a very small room with a tiny bathroom and angled ceiling on the 6th floor. The mattress was visibly and significantly caved in the middle. We were shocked to say the least. We explained that this is not what was represented and asked if they had any rooms like those pictured on their website. Fortunately, they had two others and let us look at both of them. Both were on the 1st floor and were spacious and attractive like those pictured. But one of them again had a mattress that was visibly caved in the middle and was on the street side, with very loud traffic noise even through the closed windows. We chose the other, mostly because it looked like it had an okay mattress (though very worn) and was quieter. We were content with our choice: two big dressers to put our clothes in, a large bathroom, attractive, and typically Parisian. Unfortunately, we discovered that even though this bed wasn’t visibly caved, it was in reality caved, lumpy, and extremely uncomfortable. As another reviewer wrote, it also got unbearably hot with the heaters and we were forced to keep the windows open which caused the radiators to crackle and pop very loudly all night long. Being on the first floor, we could also feel the room rattle every time the metro train went by, which was quite frequently. By the next morning, we were exhausted, having slept very little. Then when it came time for showers, there was almost no water coming out of the shower head, not even enough to get the shampoo out (my husband worked on it for a while and it got better but was still quite bad)—so forced to take baths and wash hair under the running faucet. This continued for the first four nights of our visit. We had scheduled a trip to London in the middle of our Paris trip (thank God!!) and by the time it came to leave, we couldn’t have been happier to check out. Fortunately the hotel we stayed in in London was very nice (and cheaper) with excellent beds, and we were finally able to get some sleep. Upon our return, we were given a room on the 6th floor with a completely disfigured mattress—significant mountains and valleys all over. I’ve honestly never seen anything like it. The room was also small with a bathroom so small that only one of us could stand in it at a time (and this was a superior double!). They had no other room to give us, it was late Christmas Eve, and since we hadn’t researched anywhere else to stay, we agreed to stay. We flipped the mattress which made it somewhat better. We slept awful again with the same heat and mattress problems, but this time in addition we had extremely loud plumbing noises that sounded like a waterfall coming into our bathroom every time someone flushed the toilet. By the next morning we figured out what was going on—there literally was a waterfall coming into our bathroom. Some of the pipes were broken and every time someone flushed the toilet their raw sewage was pouring onto our bathroom floor. At this point, I felt pretty resigned to dealing with it and just getting through the next three days, but my husband was so horrified (Thank God) that he demanded another room. The entire time we were there, the staff was overwhelmingly UNhelpful, but this time there was a different person at the desk that my husband spoke to. She was very sympathetic and offered to give us a suite for the price of a superior double. We moved into the suite on the 3rd floor—again another mattress with visible caving in the middle. The bathroom had an awful smell of urine, the TV was broken, the room was overheated, and filled up with exhaust fumes in the morning when the windows were open. By our last night, at about 3:00 am, my husband pulled out one of the chairs that turns into a twin bed and exclaimed, “Oh my God, it’s actually comfortable!” A word about the staff: with the exception of one person (a young woman who spoke excellent English and was very kind), the staff was pretty much completely unwilling to help. A month before our stay I contacted the hotel and asked them if they would be able to help with recommendations for Christmas dinner since from what I could tell most restaurants would be closed that day. The woman I spoke to told me it was too early to ask and told me to contact them two weeks before Christmas. So I emailed them two weeks before and was told that they would provide that information when we arrived. When we arrived, my husband asked the older woman (not the young helpful one) at the desk and she said she didn’t have any recommendations to give us. Then when we asked again upon our return on Christmas Eve, the man at the desk said he had nothing to recommend. I explained that we really needed help with this and that they agreed to help. I asked him if he would be willing to do some research and find out what was open. The man had the gall to tell me to go research it on my own on their computer! I told him that I had already spent several hours on the internet trying to find something but was not successful because I didn’t speak the language, and didn’t know the city and what resources to look at. He said, “Well whatever I find you could just find yourself.” I said to him very assertively, “No, it’s appropriate for you to do this. It’s part of your job. When we return from dinner, I expect you to have this information” Very quickly, he had a restaurant and made reservations for us. Why was it necessary for us to go through that? I also emailed the hotel prior to our stay asking for help with getting Louvre tickets. I said that I had heard that you can avoid the long lines by purchasing the tickets in advance, and asked if they had tickets themselves (a common service of most concierges) or had a way of getting them. I received a very terse and rude reply, “No, it is not possible for us to go and stand in line for you to get your tickets for you,” and then she wrote the word Louvre in all caps because I had misspelled it. When I received this reply, and being upset enough to want to cancel my reservation, I decided it must have been due to a language barrier and gave them the benefit of the doubt, but having experienced the lack of hospitality there, I now know that it wasn’t. My husband and I have stayed in many hotels throughout Europe and South America at comparable or cheaper prices, and I can honestly say that this is the worst hotel experience we have ever had. Some of the rooms are spacious and attractive and it is in a very convenient location, but unless they buy new mattresses and undergo some significant renovations (heaters, plumbing, etc) and hire new staff that is actually interested in helping, I cannot possibly recommend this hotel. Having gone through the experience, although I never would have imagined saying it, I would recommend staying at a cookie-cutter, boring Ibis for a comparable or cheaper rate. At least there you’ll get some sleep.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel, Great Location”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Having visited Paris five times previously, staying in hotels at around the 100 euro mark, I believe that the Hotel Langlois, represents the best value for money that I have experienced in Paris. We stayed over Xmas and paid 96 euros per night. The rooms are clean and pleasantly decorated with antiques, and our bathroom had recently been renovated. Staff are very helpeful (confirming dinner reservations, making restaurant recomendations, and printing directions and metro information). The hotel is in an excellent location, only a 5 min walk from Opera. The Metro stop "Trinite" is less than a two minute walk away. A taxi stand is located at the end of the street (approx 5 euros to Gare de Nord Station, 9 euros to St. Germain, 7 euros to Champs Eleysee). There is also a fantastic Bistro called "Le Bistro des Deux Theatres" near the hotel, at 18, rue Blanche. Turn left outside the hotel, and then take first street on your right - continue for about 200m and you will hit rue Blanche. We had dinner here on Xmas Eve, and it was one of the best meals we had in Paris (33 euros for champagne cocktail, 3 course meal, bottle of wine and coffee!!!) Hotel Langois, is NOT a 5 star hotel, but if you are looking for a hotel in an excellent location, that is clean and great value - you really can't beat Hotel Langlois. I thoroughly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Good value and great location”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Like many people, we booked this hotel because of the reviews it has received. We weren't disappointed, especially in view of the price we paid (96 Euros per room per night, for a double) and my experience of other Paris hotels in this price bracket. Most of the comments in the other reviews are true: large rooms, very nice decor, and attention to detail. Unfortunately the bathroom size seems to depend on the amount you pay - our room was in the low end of the price bracket and we had a tiny bathroom! It was nice and clean, but basically wouldn't do for 'larger' people! One more thing to flag up: it is an old building and has very thin walls, as well as creaky floorboards. On one night the heating was on quite high I think, with the result that the old radiator in our room was making a banging noise for quite a few hours. It didn't bother us much as we'd packed earplugs, but there's no way we could have slept through it otherwise! All in all I'd definitely stay at the Hotel Langlois again - you're not going to find a hotel with as much charm and individuality for the price in Paris. Just remember to take some earplugs if you're anything but a heavy sleeper...!

Reviews.Title: “A Gem Of A Hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: A lovely hotel in a great location - the nearest Metro stop is Trinite which is only a few steps from the hotel and from there you can be in any part of the city in a very short time. The hotel is also only 5 minutes walk away from Blvd Haussman where you will find some of the major Paris department stores including Printemps and Galleries Lafeyette. Overall the hotel was clean and the staff were friendly and welcoming. The rooms are large and traditionally French (from the era of the Belle Epoche) and the rate per night is very reasonable. I would have no hesitation in recommending the Hotel Langlois no matter what the purpose of your trip, be it business or pleasure.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely and convenient but not outstanding”
Reviews.Author: JackTheTraveller
Reviews.Content: This is a nice hotel in a very good location, close to the big department stores, a few nice brasseries, and very close to the subway. To accomodate 2 relatively grown up children, we reserved a suite and got the one on the 4th floor, facing the street. We were also offered a studio on the 7th floor but decided not to try it. The room was very nice and clean and fairly large by Paris standards. One of our problems was that the heat worked too well and we needed to open the window but the street was so noisy that we had to close it. So during the nights, we played open/close the window to maintain a relatively normal temperature in the room and to reduce the dryness. The breakfast is a bit expensive for what they offer. There is a computer available to use and to check email and that is very convenient. The reception is receptive. We used a taxi from CDG back and forth and paid about 50 Euros each way for 4 people and 3 suitcases. Due to the noise level, I would not return to the hotel during the summer months but would consider it in the winter. BTW, the prices mentioned in TripAdvisor are not realisitic. Rooms are much more expensive, about 100 euros is the minimun you are likely to pay.

Reviews.Title: “Wish we could have stayed longer!!! We loved it!!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We chose to stay here based on the Trip Advisor reviews, and it lived up to everyone's high remarks! We absolutely loved it! For the price, you cannot beat this hotel! Our honeymoon was 2 weeks long, 6 of those nights in Paris (4 at the beginning of the trip at a different hotel, 2 in the end of the trip at the Langlois), and we chose a slightly cheaper hotel for the first 4 nights. I wish we had stayed in this hotel the whole time! It was so cute and really very charming. I loved this location. At first, I looked at a map and thought that it looked like it was slightly far from the monuments, but it really isn't! And not to mention the fact that the metro stop is SO close...just at the end of the street! There are so many little restaurants close to the hotel and there is a great little wine shop just across and down the street towards the church (the owner of the wine shop is so nice and spoke great English). The hotel is also very close to Au Printemps and Galleries Lafayette (shopping). Also, there is a great little creperie near the metro stop. The room that we had was great. It was on the 5th floor and had a great view of the street and the huge church/cathedral (not sure???) and the tops of the buildings. We loved the room. It was very very big by Parisian standards, and it was just very comfortable! Again....we loved it! From reading a couple of other reviews, I noticed something that I strongly disagree with, not about the hotel itself, but rather getting to the hotel. I read that the other reviewers only paid about 40 Euros for a taxi ride to the hotel, but we took a taxi for one leg of our airport travels to and from Paris city center. We were charged 60 Euros for 2 people with 3 suitcases. We knew that we were being majorly ripped off, but we couldn't do anything about it. The other 3 legs of our airport traveling, we used a company called "Airport Connection," (you have to pre-book them over the internet) and we loved them. Don't book them if you expect a super-quick trip (it takes aprx 45 mins-1 hour to Paris from the airport & vice versa), but they are reliable and have the cheapest price I could find anywhere! Their website is ----------. We loved their service. =) Overall, I just absolutely loved this hotel and the neighborhood it was situated in. The true testament is to ask "Would I stay there again?" and the answer is without a doubt YES! Stay there....you won't be disappointed!

Reviews.Title: “Great Value for Money”
Reviews.Author: daphnelok
Reviews.Content: I stayed in Hotel Langlois with my family on the 5 to 10 Nov. We stayed in room 14 on the first night, no air-con and it was noisy even with the lightest traffic. We requested to stay at the top floor and was given the change the next night. Room 64 was great, bigger than room 14 and noise level was lower. The bed was ok however the pillows were too soft. The hotel is warm and cosy with friendly staff. The room is clean and tidy. The staffs are helpful and they speak english. Hotels are very expensive in Paris, and for the price I have paid for , I would say this hotel offers great value for money. It was our first trip to Paris, we managed to find our ways around the city. Most of the musesums and monuments can be reached using the metro. You will find bakeries, cafes, chinese food down the streets. Taxi trip from the hotel to CDG airport cost abt 40 euros.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely, but not quite 5 star”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We booked this hotel mainly due to the reviews on this site. It is a lovely, clean, friendly hotel.......we had a great stay. However, I wouldn't give it 5 stars for a couple of reasons. Firstly, the walls are paper thin!! We could hear people outside our room and a lot of noise from upstairs (even when someone was using the loo in the room above!!!). Also, the hot water ran out one morning and we had semi-tepid showers. Altogether, a lovely stay, great location, would definatley go back, but I have stayed in more comfortable hotels.

Reviews.Title: “Everything as promised!”
Reviews.Author: Jinkyhenke
Reviews.Content: It's comforting to know that Tripadvisor ratings are reliable, and the Hotel des Croises certainly lived up to its ratings when we visited in early October. The staff in this delighful hotel were quietly courteous and efficient. They offered a very helpful service, which included some assistance that went well beyond the minimalist approach often adopted in modern hotels. Enough has been said about the unique charms of this establishment in other postings:they are all true! The room size was exceptional,and the room rate offered quite stunning value for money.This is not a luxury hotel, but offers much that one would not expect in this price range. Another attractive feature of a stay here is the accessibility of the location. Only one minute's walk from The Metro, we reached the hotel in only 20 minutes from the airport bus terminus; the major sights are all within a short Metro ride and made easier with a tourist transport pass which was well worth buying.There are limitless eating places, and even if you head for the Left Bank, you may eat well within even the tightest budget. We have no decision to make when we next head for Paris; we shall be staying at the Hotel des Croises.

Reviews.Title: “The high ratings are well-deserved!!!”
Reviews.Author: florida45
Reviews.Content: My wife and I just returned to Florida after a four night stay at the charming Hotel Langlois in Paris. We found the positive reviews on Tripadvisor to be very, very accurate. The hotel is comfortable and immaculate, with recently upgraded furnishings and decor. The staff was extremely helpful and friendly. Breakfast was excellent. The street/neighborhood is safe and in a convenient location.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely Langlois”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The best hotel we've stayed in Paris so far (5 others not worth a revisit). Clean, stylish and economical. the restaurant recommendations from the staff were also first class. Very convenient for moving around the city, some local pastry shops and bars closed at the weekends, but plenty are open. Its cheaper to have a coffee and croissant in a nearby cafe, however the buffet breakfast is good value. Will definately go back.

Reviews.Title: “Bargain Hotel in central Paris”
Reviews.Author: MI4
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Hotel Langlois in Paris for 4 nights in September 2005. We chose it after reading the reviews in TripAdvisor and can now happily echo the sentiments of the reviewers. Despite the awful exchange rate from Australian dollars to Euros, we decided to take advantage of the relatively low room rates at this hotel by booking a suite for not much more money. It proved to be a great decision, as the rooms were very spacious with really high ceilings, marble fireplaces, antique statues, and large double windows opening out onto a relatively quiet one-way street. The building is quite old and the parquetry floors creaked a little, but the rooms were spotless, the elevator worked, the plumbing was good and the ensuite just fine. The staff were experienced, helping us with our (great many) questions. There was free internet access from a computer in the breakfast/sitting room downstairs. We chose not to pay the little extra for breakfast there, but instead opted to eat out which is what you have to do in Paris. The location was perfect. Everything was within easy reach even by foot, so we walked nearly everywhere. The train station for Versailles was a 10 minute walk. There was a metro station within 200 metres, and a great number of theatres, shops, restaurants, bistrots, cafes, and convenience stores all around. The opera house is nearby as are the 2 famous department stores. We took the metro one memorable evening to Sacre Couer and, after dinner in Montmartre, walked back down the hill to our hotel through interesting lanes via the more "vibrant" Pigalle district (Moulin Rouge, nightclubs, bars, etc) for a rounded view of what makes Paris so... Parisien. We can highly recommend the Hotel Langlois as a central part of anyone's Paris visit.

Reviews.Title: “Very friendly and helpful staff, great hotel, full of character”
Reviews.Author: coolcookie
Reviews.Content: I stayed at this hotel with my two little boys. The staff were very friendly and helpful. The room was very comfortable, all your home comforts. Couldn't fault it at all. I'd definitely stay here again, no question. There was a great sandwich bar just at the end of the street too, very good and reasonable.

Reviews.Title: “Very Happy with the Hotel Langlois”
Reviews.Author: EuropeanAmerican
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Hotel Langlois from Sept 24th through Sept 29th 2005. I did a lot of research through Tripadvisor and I am pleased with our choice for the hotel. The positives you read in the other reviews are true. I was mainly impressed by the staff, specifically the two young women who staff the front desk. They were very helpful when we had questions about where to find a store to buy food for a picnic (the Galleries Lafayette has a gourmet food section), where to find a laundry (walk out the front door of the Hotel, take a right and it's a 5 minute walk on St. Lazare and is on the right) and how to find the Hard Rock Cafe' - Paris (it's on Boulevard Hausmann - we only went there for a souvenier for a friend). I'd also like to put in a plug for the guys at the panini / crepe stand attached to the Royal Trinite' cafe. The panini's are great (try the l'espangnol) and the cooks are really friendly.

Reviews.Title: “Very good indeed”
Reviews.Author: rttn
Reviews.Content: Now. This hotel is perfect. Really. Since there is no air condition in the rooms the hotel, by french standards, gets a maximum of two stars (one star?). The class is much higher though. I'm giving only 4 stars due to the fact that the hotel had accepted more reservations than they have rooms. We had to stay at Hotel Brittany the first night (out of four) and that was not a pleasant experience (avoid that hotel at any cost!). I figure this is something they do on a regular basis due to the popularity.

Reviews.Title: “Paris without attitude”
Reviews.Author: UK_SimonG
Reviews.Content: Like many others I booked this based on the reviews from this website - and was not disappointed. The front desk staff could not have been more helpful - and even ensured we got to the airport on time despite the metre/RER strike, by warning us of the strike and then booking an early taxi. Room on the 6th floor was wonderful - lots of character and with air conditioning – not that it was needed. It is an old hotel and you do hear some noise from other rooms and the lift – and why some people need showers/baths at 6am on a Sunday …… This is the best Paris hotel I have stayed in (out of circa 10 others) and would highly recommend it to people who want character, space, excellent and proactive reception staff and who accept the occasional noise you get in an old/character hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent stay”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We chose this hotel based on the reviews and further research. Before making the our stop here, we stayed at a different, more expensive hotel - what a mistake. The hotel is great for the price and the staff is really helpful. I will stay here on my next visit.

Reviews.Title: “Elegance and Value”
Reviews.Author: MattB
Reviews.Content: A small, family operated hotel that is conveniently located. It is possible to walk to most areas of interest from the hotel. Our room was spaceous, clean, and well decorated. The elevator is vintage, and small, so the stairs are sometimes a better option. Breakfast is offered in classic style (fresh pastries, fruit, and coffee). For the price, one of the best values we have ever encountered.

Reviews.Title: “Incroyable Indeed! Loved this Paris hotel!”
Reviews.Author: iantraveller
Reviews.Content: We stayed in Paris for several night with our three young children. We had two rooms on the 4th floor and were pleasantly surprised by the quality owe found. We selected this hotel based on Trip Advisor reviews and we found exactly what people said we would ... an amazing little hotel, in a fantastic location, with beautiful rooms and friendly helpful staff. Our kids enjoyed riding the lift each day and I appreciated having access to teh internet to stay on top of work back home (although my wife constantly chastised me!) This hotel is a real gem and I wish I wasn't so glowing for fear I won't be able to get a reservation next time but it was simply outstanding value. The location was very convenient and just minuted from the Metro station. There was a bank machine and post office just down the street and excellent restaurants within a few metres of the hotel in every direction. My family amd I just had a dreamy vacation in Paris and I can't wait to go back to the Hotel Des Croises when we return to Paris again one day!

Reviews.Title: “Great Value, Good Location”
Reviews.Author: WindshearDon
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Hotel Langlois based on reviews found on TripAdvisor. It exceeded all our expectations. We wanted a quiet place which was well-situated for a brief visit in Paris while we got over our jet lag. It offered a lot more. We were able to get to the hotel by train from Aeroport Charles de Gaulle easily (40 mins) and quickly with our bags in tow. The hotel's location is between Opera Garnier and Montmarte on a quiet and safe street. The Metro is 50 steps away. It is near all the big department stores and has some nice cafes in the neighbourhood. The hotel's rooms are huge by European standards and some of the bathrooms (we were travelling with friends) are enormous by any standard. In the middle of summer - the air conditioning (remote controlled) was very efficient and QUIET! Their is also a small fridge in each room. The beds are great and cleaning staff keep the rooms immaculate. The buffet continental breakfast is quite nice and is not exhorbitantly priced compared to the cafes. The elevator is a wonderful relic that will hopefully stay in service for many more decades. Reception was friendly and efficient. There is also an internet computer available to guests (except during breakfast). The downside is that there are very limited views and limited service in the hotel. The halls are a bit musty and the TVs are small with only a dozen channels. If you came to Paris to enjoy getting out on the city and want a hotel offering great value (110 euros per room) and a sound sleep then this is it. You can spend your savings on great restaurants instead! By the way - try Deux Theatres - a five minute walk from Hotel Langlois.

Reviews.Title: “Incroyable!!! We loved this hotel... more than worth the money.”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Hotel Langlois during our honeymoon the week of July 10th, 2005. We stayed in a variety of different hotels during our trip to Europe, including a Chateau outside Paris, and we both feel without a doubt that the Hotel Langlois was our favorite place that we stayed. If you are looking to experience some Romantic charm and you want a good place to start exploring Paris from then this is definitely a great place. My wife and I arrived in Paris via Gare Du Nord. The Hotel Langlois is accessible from Gare Du Nord by taking a Metro train to St. Lazare Station (one stop). It will take some navigating to find the E train but if you are carrying heavy bags you will find this to be an easier way to go. Once you arrive in St. Lazare Station you can connect to Line 12 and go north one stop to Trinite station however I would not recommend this if you are not comfortable carrying your bags up approximately 20 steps. St. Lazare Station is approximately 2.5 blocks from Hotel Langlois and there are escalators/elevators that can take you up to street level. Stopping at this station will require a little more walking but looking back we found this an easier way to go (arrived and departed via this station). Walking through the front door of the Hotel Langlois you almost feel like you are walking back in time or into a game of "Myst". We were given room 54 which exceeded all expectations. If you are carrying a lot of bags you may have some difficulty with the elevator. I remember riding up and down the elevator just for the fun of it though on several occasions. If you have ever played Riven or Myst I think you will get a kick out of this place. Room 54 was more than we could have asked for.
